constraint.name: General purpose: used in many different contexts

methodInfo.name: Affinity diagramming
methodInfo.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

methodInfo.name: Card sorting
methodInfo.description: A method for organizing information that involves sorting a series of cards into groups that make sense to the participants.

methodInfo.name: Claims analysis
methodInfo.description: A technique for examining the positive and negative consequences of design features that are described in current or future scenarios of use.

methodInfo.name: Cognitive task analysis
methodInfo.description: A collection of methods that can be used to understand work that involves decision-making and problem solving.

methodInfo.name: Cognitive walkthrough
methodInfo.description: A usability evaluation method in which one or more evaluators step through tasks derived from an analysis of the context of use, and ask specific questions about the user's ability to perform each action.

methodInfo.name: Common Industry Specification for Usability Requirements
methodInfo.description: Supports defining usability requirements in sufficient detail to make an effective contribution to design and development, and defining usability criteria that can be empirically validated subsequently if needed.

methodInfo.name: Competitor analysis
methodInfo.description: Identifying the strengths and weaknesses of competing products or services before starting work on prototypes.

methodInfo.name: Context of use analysis
methodInfo.description: Collecting and analyzing detailed information about the intended users, their tasks, and the technical and environmental constraint.

methodInfo.name: Contextual inquiry
methodInfo.description: A semi-structured field interviewing method based on a set of principles that allow it to be molded to different situations. This technique is generally used at the beginning of the design process and is good for getting rich information, but can be complex and time consuming.

methodInfo.name: Critical incident technique
methodInfo.description: A method of gathering facts (incidents) from domain experts or less experienced users of the existing system to gain knowledge of how to improve the performance of the individuals involved.

methodInfo.name: Cultural probe
methodInfo.description: Sets of simple artifacts (such as maps, postcards, cameras, or diaries) that are given to users for them to record specific events, feelings or interactions in their usual environment, in order to get to know them and their culture better, to uncover aspects of culture and human interaction like emotions, values, connections, and trust.

methodInfo.name: Diary study
methodInfo.description: Users are asked to record or note specific events, feelings or interactions in their usual environment.

methodInfo.name: Ethnography
methodInfo.description: Gathering information about users and tasks directly from users in their normal work, home or leisure environment. Traditional ethnography focuses on long-term studies spanning weeks, months, or even years.

methodInfo.name: Event data analysis
methodInfo.description: Analysis of observations collected via instrumentation (e.g., keystrokes, communication logs) over time to identify patterns that evaluate use of the system.

methodInfo.name: Field study
methodInfo.description: An investigator views users as they work, taking notes on the activity that takes place, and typically asking questions.

methodInfo.name: Fishbone diagram
methodInfo.description: A graphic that is created to identify cause-and-effect relationships among factors in a given situation. It is made up of a 'head' which states a problem or effect and bones along the spine which represent factors and categories of factors.

methodInfo.name: Focus group
methodInfo.description: A focused discussion where a moderator leads a group of participants through a set of questions on a particular topic.

methodInfo.name: Formative evaluation
methodInfo.description: Evaluation that has the purpose of improving the usability of a product.

methodInfo.name: Free listing
methodInfo.description: A technique for gathering data about a specific domain or topic by asking people to list all the items they can think of that relate to the topic. It can be used to gather data in large group settings or in one-on-one interviews.

methodInfo.name: Function allocation/Task allocation
methodInfo.description: A classic human factors method for deciding whether a particular function will be accomplished by a person, technology (hardware or software) or some mix of person and technology.

methodInfo.name: Future workshop
methodInfo.description: Enables a group of people to develop new ideas or solutions to social problems, and is particularly useful when the participants who have little experience with processes of creative decision making. It emphasizes: critique, learning, team work, democracy, and empowerment.

methodInfo.name: Heuristic evaluation
methodInfo.description: A usability evaluation method in which one or more reviewers, preferably experts, compare a software, documentation, or hardware product to a list of design principles (commonly referred to as heuristics).

methodInfo.name: Heuristic walkthrough
methodInfo.description: Combines aspects of heuristic evaluation, the cognitive walkthough, and the pluralistic walkthough.

methodInfo.name: Hierarchical task analysis
methodInfo.description: One of the most widely used methods in task analysis, based on the hierarchical decomposition of a task into small pieces corresponding to intermediate goals.

methodInfo.name: Human factors analysis
methodInfo.description: Analyzes human functions, effects and influence in a system, particularly human influence on the reliability of a system It includes traditional human reliability analysis, human error analysis, man-machine interface analysis, and human character analysis.

methodInfo.name: Human performance model
methodInfo.description: Software that simulates some aspect of human performance within a limited domain. Mathematical techniques such as regression, fuzzy logic or neural networks to model human performance have been found to be able to accurately predict human behavior in a variety of domains, including visual object recognition, decision- making and temporal planning. Task network modeling uses flow diagrams to capture the steps associated with some human performance, and distributions of timing and accuracy data are associated with each step in the diagram. 'Cognitive architectures' or 'integrative architectures' attempt to simulate actual human perceptual and/or cognitive processes.

methodInfo.name: Stakeholder interviews
methodInfo.description: Questioning stakeholders to discover facts and opinions held about the system being designed.

methodInfo.name: Longitudinal study
methodInfo.description: A longitudinal study captures data over a period of time (days, week, months, or years) to understand the long-term effects of changes in products, processes, or environment.

methodInfo.name: Parallel design
methodInfo.description: A method where several design groups produce alternative designs in parallel with the objective of incorporating the best aspects of each design in the final solution.

methodInfo.name: Participatory design
methodInfo.description: An approach to design that attempts to actively involve the end users in the design process to help ensure that the product designed meets their needs and is usable.

methodInfo.name: Participatory workshop
methodInfo.description: A group activity where users and stakeholders work together to generate one or more design artifacts. The techniques for conducting participatory workshops can vary considerably, but often involve brainstorming of ideas, translation of ideas into rough designs, refinement of the design, and finally evaluation of design.

methodInfo.name: Persona
methodInfo.description: Fictional person created to model and describe the goals, needs, and characteristics of a specific type or group of users.

methodInfo.name: Phone Interview
methodInfo.description: A semi-structured or structured interview that is conducted over a phone or Internet audio line.

methodInfo.name: Photo study
methodInfo.description: A sample of users are given a set of 'missions' to take photos to highlight important aspects of their lives and day to day context. Data from these studies helps highlight opportunities for new technologies and barriers to their acceptance.

methodInfo.name: Physical ergonomics
methodInfo.description: Physical ergonomics is concerned with the impact of anatomy, anthropometry, biomechanics, physiology, and the physical environment on physical activity.

methodInfo.name: Pluralistic usability walkthrough
methodInfo.description: A usability walkthrough carried out by a group of stakeholders that can include user interface designers, users, developers, and management.

methodInfo.name: (Develop) prototypes
methodInfo.description: Prototypes are usually created as low-cost representations of the user interface to a system, as a method of brainstorming, creating, testing and communicating ideas about the system being developed.

methodInfo.name: Quality Function Deployment (QFD)
methodInfo.description: A technique that emerged from the quality movement in manufacturing that uses a variety of tools (for example, interviews, focus groups, technical support logs, field visits) to understand the 'voice of the customer', develop requirements that meet both stated and unstated needs of the customers, and generate plans for translating those requirements into the set of features that will satisfy and delight customers.

methodInfo.name: Questions, options, and criteria
methodInfo.description: A visual approach for exploring and evaluation design options against an explicit set of criteria or constraints.

methodInfo.name: Rapid prototyping
methodInfo.description: The creation of low-cost representations of the user interface to a system as a method of brainstorming, creating, testing and communicating ideas about the system being developed.

methodInfo.name: Rating Scales
methodInfo.description: A series of response options to research questions, representing degrees of a particular characteristic.

methodInfo.name: Remote evaluation
methodInfo.description: Usability testing method where the evaluator is remote from the user.

methodInfo.name: Satisfaction questionnaire
methodInfo.description: Questionnaires used to assess how users feel about the system being tested.

methodInfo.name: Scenario
methodInfo.description: A descriptions of one or more users interacting with a system, device, or process to achieve a goal under specified conditions and constraints. Scenarios are used in design sessions, walkthroughs, and usability tests to ensure that the system design effectively supports users in a wide range of real-life situations.

methodInfo.name: Storyboard
methodInfo.description: A technique for illustrating an interaction between a person and a product (or multiple people and multiple products) in narrative format, which includes a series of drawings, sketches, or pictures, and sometimes words that tell a story.

methodInfo.name: Success critical stakeholder identification
methodInfo.description: From all the users, customers and other stakeholders identify any criteria that are essential for making the project a success

methodInfo.name: Summative evaluation
methodInfo.description: Evaluation that has the purpose of assessing the extent to which usability objectives have been achieved.

methodInfo.name: SWOT
methodInfo.description: A tool for strategic planning that uses structured brainstorming to identify the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats associated with a project, product, process, or organization.

methodInfo.name: Task analysis
methodInfo.description: Analysis of how a task is accomplished, including a detailed description of both manual and mental activities, task and element durations, task frequency, task allocation, task complexity, environmental conditions, any necessary clothing and equipment, and any other unique factors involved in or required for one or more people to perform a given task.

methodInfo.name: Usability benchmarking
methodInfo.description: Measure existing values of effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction that provide a benchmark against which future systems can be compared.

methodInfo.name: Usability requirements
methodInfo.description: Requirements for the extent to which a system, product or service can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use

methodInfo.name: Usability testing
methodInfo.description: A usability evaluation method that involves observing users performing specific tasks with the system.

methodInfo.name: Usability walkthrough
methodInfo.description: A usability evaluation method in which one or more evaluators attempt to achieve goals with the product derived from an analysis of the context of use, and play the role of a user in order to identify usability problems.

methodInfo.name: Use case
methodInfo.description: The description of an interaction between an 'actor' and a system, to achieve a specific outcome. Use cases are a functional perspective on the interaction, written in an implementation-independent way - they describe what a system or process does rather than how it does something specifically. Also sometimes used to refer to a scenario.

methodInfo.name: User edit
methodInfo.description: A technique for evaluating the usability of hardcopy or online documentation, where participants provide written or verbal feedback as they use the documentation to complete a task with a product.

methodInfo.name: Web metrics/analytics
methodInfo.description: Measures of behaviour of website users. Commonly measured data includes page hits and visits, paths taken through a website, abandonment rates, conversion rates, feature usage, and frequency of errors.

methodInfo.name: Wireframe
methodInfo.description: Rough outline of navigation and content elements that make up a user interface. Typically visual design and precise layout are not addressed.

methodInfo.name: Wizard of Oz
methodInfo.description: User-based evaluation of unimplemented technology by using a human to simulate the response of a system.

methodInfo.name: Work context analysis
methodInfo.description: Context of use analysis, with emphasis on identifying stakeholders, and the enterprise and environmental contexts.

methodInfo.name: Work domain analysis
methodInfo.description: Analysis of the functional structure of the engineered system or domain for complex systems: the goals to be achieved in the domain, and the means available for achieving those goals. This provides the framework for identifying the tasks to be performed by humans and the cognitive activities those entail.

methodInfo.name: Workload assessment
methodInfo.description: Assessment of the amount of work assigned to or expected from a worker in a specified time period and the associated mental workload. Can be measured objectively, or subjectively by the operator.

methodInfo.name: KLM-GOMS
methodInfo.description: Part of the GOMS family of predictive models, the Keystroke-Level Model GOMS (KLM-GOMS) is a quantitative modeling tool for predicting how long it will take expert users to complete a specific task with no errors. KLM-GOMS predicts task times based on a simple set of physical and mental operators including keystrokes, button clicks, pointer movement, keyboard to mouse movement, and thinking time. To obtain the predicted time for a task, you add the times for individual operators.

activity.name: Analysis
activity.description: This activity consists on grouping a set of usability concepts and techniques based on the identification and comprehension of the users needs according to their features, their problems and the context where they are inmerse

subactivity.name: User Analysis
subactivity.description: Analysis of the potential users that will use the system

method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

method.name: Affinity diagramming 2
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

subactivity.name: Task Analysis
subactivity.description: To know how the user works and do his tasks with the current resources

method.name: Affinity diagramming 8
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

subactivity.name: Concept Product Design
subactivity.description: To think of what kind of features must be satisfied according to the current user needs

method.name: Affinity diagramming 9
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

subactivity.name: Prototyping
subactivity.description: Development of rapid prototypes to see common mistakes and think how to fix them

method.name: Affinity diagramming 10
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

method.name: Affinity diagramming 11
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

subactivity.name: Requirements Specification
subactivity.description: To establish a set of requierements or usability objectives that a developer must to improve the user experience

method.name: Affinity diagramming 12
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

method.name: Affinity diagramming 13
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

method.name: Affinity diagramming 14
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

method.name: Affinity diagramming 15
method.description: A participatory method where concepts written on cards are sorted into logical groups on the wall

subactivity.name: Requirements Validation
subactivity.description: Checking if the system satisfies the usability objectives marked to correct the UX

activity.name: Design
activity.description: Design activity consists on several ideas and methods that try to help a developer to understand and design the user interaction and the interface based on his behaviour at the time of using the system

subactivity.name: Interaction Design
subactivity.description: Group of methods to help a developer thinking how a user interacts with the system and how to avoid his mistakes

subactivity.name: General Design
subactivity.description: Group of methods to help a developer thinking how a user interacts with the system and how to avoid his mistakes

activity.name: Evaluation
activity.description: This activity tries to recommend some quite useful techniques to catch and correct errors on a new or existing system with potential users, usability experts or performance metrics in order to improve the user experience

subactivity.name: Expert Evaluation
subactivity.description: Useful but complex techniques that requieres an expert colaboration to inspect and evaluate the system behaviour

subactivity.name: Usability Tests
subactivity.description: Set of techniques that involve potential users who does not know how the system works and represent a concrete profile

subactivity.name: Monitoring Studies
subactivity.description: Evaluations of existing methods using some perfomance or user interaction metrics, reporting a feedback that could be used to improve the usability

stage.name: Analysis
stage.description: During inception, you establish the business rationale for the project and decide on the scope of the project. This is when you get the commitment from the project sponsor to go further. Therefore, the focus is on handling the risks related to the business case: Is this project financially worthy? Is it feasible?

bestPractice.name: Identify expected context of use of systems [forthcoming needs, trends and expectations]
Analyze the system concept [to clarify objectives, their viability and risks]
Describe the objectives which the user or user organization wants to achieve through use of the system.
Define the scope of the context of use for the system.
Identify and analyze the roles of each group of stakeholders likely to be affected by the system.

stage.name: Design
stage.description: In elaboration, you collect more detailed requirements, do more extensive design and you establish the baseline software architecture. The main focus is on the technical risks, exploring the main technical decisions, and maybe revisiting the scope again, as the requirements become better understood.

bestPractice.name: Identify and analyze the roles of each group of stakeholders likely to be affected by the system.
Describe the characteristics of the users.
Describe the cultural environment/ organizational/ management regime.
Describe the characteristics of any equipment external to the system and the working environment.
Describe the location, workplace equipment and ambient conditions.
Decide the goals, behaviours and tasks of the organization that influence human resources
Present context and human resources options and constraints to the project stakeholders.
Analyze the tasks and work system.
Perform research into required system usability.
Generate design options for each aspect of the system related to its use and its effect on stakeholders.
Produce user-centred solutions for each design option.
Analyze the implications of the context of use.
Develop an explicit statement of the user requirements for the system.
Generate and agree on measurable criteria for the system in its intended context of use.
Identify, specify and produce the infrastructure for the system.
Build required competencies into training and awareness programs
Define the global numbers, skills and supporting equipment needed to achieve those tasks.
Assess the extent to which usability criteria and other HS requirements are likely to be met by the proposed design.
Analyze the user requirements.
Present these requirements to project stakeholders for use in the development and operation of the system.
Develop simulation or trial implementation of key aspects of the system for the purposes of testing with users.
Identify any staffing gap and communicate requirement to design of staffing solutions.

stage.name: Evaluation
stage.description: During construction, you carry out the mass of work for detailed design and implementation activities. The focus is on the logistical risks; on making every design decision taken previously fit into the built system. The result of this stage is something that can be installed at the ends user workplace, which can be part of the system or the whole system.

bestPractice.name: Generate design options for each aspect of the system related to its use and its effect on stakeholders.
Produce user-centred solutions for each design option.
Design to enable customization to support specific market and user needs.
Distribute functions between the human, machine and organizational elements of the system best able to fulfil each function.
Develop a model of the user's work from the requirements, context of use, allocation of function and design constraints for the system.
Produce designs for the user-related elements of the system that take account of the user requirements, context of use and human factors data.
Produce a description of how the system will be used to support integration of system components.
Analyze gap between existing and future provision
Collect user input on the usability of the developing system.
